pages.title: ⎧ Knight of Wands ⎧
pages.text: Heir of Flame and Lightning$(br)       ∆ Fire of ∆ Fire

The Knight of Wands sits on their horse in full armor, wearing a yellow robe, and a helmet with fiery red plumes flowing behind them.$(br)  Passing mounds or pyramids in the desert, they are shown as if upon a journey; armed only with a short wand, though armored, they are not prepared for war.$(br)  Their horse rises up on its hind legs, poised and leaping to action.$(br)  The motion of the horse is a key to the character of its

rider, and suggests the precipitate mood, or things connected therewith.$(br)  Knights, as figures of action, instinct, and even violence, have only the code of chivalry to anchor them in civilization.$(br)  A knight is defined by what they do in the world, not by who they are.$(br)  The knight's heroism, their courage, and virtue keep the flame alive, if faintly, in the hard world of real life.$(br)  The card has a certain

purity and idealism therein. $(br2)$(l)Divinatory meanings$()$(br)  Departure, emigration.$(br)  May symbolize someone courageous, idealistic, virtuous; maybe headstrong, refusing to compromise what they believe is right.$(br2)$(l)Reversed$()$(br)  Rupture, interruption, loss of idealism.$(br)  May symbolize someone who has taken a lot of risks and is possibly in some danger.
